trans-unit.source: Controls the deceleration of a rotation manipulation during inertia.
The <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior> class specifies how a rotation manipulation behaves when it is inertia.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.ManipulationInertiaStartingEventArgs.RotationBehavior%2A> property in the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.ManipulationInertiaStarting> event to do the following:
Specify the initial velocity of the inertia when it begins by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.InitialVelocity%2A> property.
Specify the desired rotation of the manipulation when inertia ends by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredRotation%2A> property.
Specify the desired deceleration of the inertia by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredDeceleration%2A> property.
Set either the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredRotation%2A> or the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredDeceleration%2A>, but not both.
When you set one of these properties, the other property is changed to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> if it has a value.
For more information about manipulations, see the [Input Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/input-overview.md).

For an example of an application that responds to manipulations, see [Walkthrough: Creating Your First Touch Application](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/walkthrough-creating-your-first-touch-application.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior"></xref> class.
Gets or sets the rate the rotation slows in degrees per squared millisecond.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredDeceleration%2A> property to specify the desired deceleration of the inertia.
Set either the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredRotation%2A> or the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredDeceleration%2A>, but not both.
When you set one of these properties, the other property is changed to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> if it has a value.
For more information about manipulations, see the [Input Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/input-overview.md).

For an example of an application that responds to manipulations, see [Walkthrough: Creating Your First Touch Application](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/walkthrough-creating-your-first-touch-application.md).
The rate the rotation slows in degrees per squared millisecond.
The default is <xref href="System.Double.NaN"></xref>.
The property is set to infinity.
-or-
The property is set to <xref href="System.Double.NaN"></xref>.
Gets or sets the rotation, in degrees, at the end of the inertial movement.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredRotation%2A> property to specify the desired rotation of the manipulation when inertia ends.
Set either the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredRotation%2A> or the <xref:System.Windows.Input.InertiaRotationBehavior.DesiredDeceleration%2A>, but not both.
When you set one of these properties, the other property is changed to <xref:System.Double.NaN?displayProperty=fullName> if it has a value.
For more information about manipulations, see the [Input Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/input-overview.md).

For an example of an application that responds to manipulations, see [Walkthrough: Creating Your First Touch Application](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/walkthrough-creating-your-first-touch-application.md).
The rotation, in degrees, at the end of the inertial movement.
The default is <xref href="System.Double.NaN"></xref>.
Gets or sets the initial rate of the rotation at the start of the inertia phase.
For more information about manipulations, see the [Input Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/input-overview.md).

For an example of an application that responds to manipulations, see [Walkthrough: Creating Your First Touch Application](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/walkthrough-creating-your-first-touch-application.md).
The initial rate of the rotation at the start of the inertia phase.
